bibl.title: Letter from J.F. Siler to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 12, 1949

div1.p: Siler does not think Hench should attend the Reed Memorial Association meeting if his health does not approve.

div1.head: Letter from J.F. Siler to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 12, 1949
div1.opener:
GORGAS MEMORIAL INSTITUTE
OF
TROPICAL AND PREVENTIVE MEDICINE
INCORPORATED
1835 EYE STREET, NORTHWEST
WASHINGTON 6, D. C.
September 12, 1949
EXECUTIVE OFFICES
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
Your note of September 10th enclosing the card from
Doctor Hench reached me a few minutes ago. I am delighted
that he is well enough to go back home again. I doubt very
much if he received my letter before leaving Colorado Springs
but I am sure that it will be forwarded on to him immediately.
I note that he may be here in Washington on September 20th but
apparently his stay will be a very short one. I assume that he
intends coming to New York the latter part of October and then,
if he is well enough, coming on down to attend the annual meet-
ing here in Washington. In view of the fact that there is nothing
special to come up before the Walter Reed annual meeting except
the possibility of continuing the extra amount granted to Mrs.
Reed last year, I do not think that Dr. Hench should put himself
to any trouble to come down unless he feels up to it physically.

J. R. K-
thinks so too

Kate and I are still hoping to get around to see you and
Mrs. Kean in a few days. She has not been very well recently and
is now going through a number of tests at Walter Reed including
X-Ray surveys of her gastro-intestinal tract.
div1.closer:
Faithfully yours, J. F. Siler If Mrs Reed should die in the next month we would have to decide whether
we should give her allowance to Blossom, who I hear has made inquiries
about it. I think that it would be well to decide this matter next month-
If you decide not to come I hope you will give your proxy to Siler or me-
Our wish and prayer for you is that you do not undertake anything new
or that can be avoided-
Affectionately
J. R. Kean
(over)
Ac
RT
P. S. I have received thru Col. Siler's activ-
ity ten copies very nicely gotten up of the
addresses made on the Evening of May 12-
1948 by Gen Bless, Dr. Soper and yourself-
It seems that the State Dept has no more
copies but the Public Health had secured
400 and in some way Dr W. H. Wright-cha
chairman of the Intersociety Committee got
some of them and has sent me 10 at the
request of Col. Siler- J. R. K
Excuse my use of Silers letter- This does not
need an answer-
